Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 continues with the adventures of Peter Quill/Star-Lord(Chris Pratt), Rocket(Bradley Cooper), Drax(Dave Bautista), Groot(Vin Diesel), Nebula(Karen Gillan), Mantis(Pom Klementieff) & Kraglin(Sean Gunn), after the events of Avengers: Endgame(2019) & The Guardians of the Galaxy Holiday Special(2022). Still grieving over the loss of Gamora(Zoe Saldana), Peter & the rest of the Guardians go on a new mission to safeguard the universe & save one of their own. However, if they don't succeed, it could mean dire consequences for the Guardians.

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 is an awe-inspiring film. Writer-director James Gunn has given us a movie that is action-packed, hilarious, emotional & heartbreaking. Gunn takes you on a rollercoaster ride of emotions, throughout the course of the film. The action set pieces are mind-blowing. The visual effects are brilliant. The 3D is eye-popping, especially in IMAX. The banter & camaraderie among all the Guardians, is a delight to watch. The performances are the highlight of the movie. Chris Pratt is superb as Peter Quill/Star-Lord. Bradley Cooper is spectacular as Rocket. Chukwudi Iwuji is phenomenal as The High Evolutionary. Iwuji is right up there as one of the best villains in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Pom Klementieff is fantastic as Mantis. Dave Bautista is hysterical as Drax. Karen Gillan is excellent as Nebula. Vin Diesel is good as Groot. Zoe Saldana is amazing as Gamora. Will Poulter is awesome as Adam Warlock. Sean Gunn is great as Kraglin. The supporting cast is unforgettable. Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 is a must watch for fans of the titular characters & the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Watch it on the biggest screen possible & get ready to be blown away!

This movie puts every single superhero movie made since endgame to shame. It is the perfect balance of dark, goofy, and dramatic. Rockets origin story is heartbreaking and done perfectly. As soon as I heard James Gunn was coming back to direct it, I had no doubt in my mind that this movie would be amazing. I knew it would be good, but this was perfect. The villain is so great at making you hate him (which is what they're supposed to do). The High Evolutionary is a top 5 marvel villain and the actor plays him flawlessly.

Every single guardian has a special moment and gets to shine. Rocket and Star Lord lead this movie. They are the heart of this film.

This movie made me cry twice (I never cry at movies). Rocket is more than anybody could've expected. If you had told me in 2013 that a talking raccoon would made me cry in a movie theater, then I wouldn't have believed you.

Every single superhero movie maker should look up to this and say "this is a model of what I want." It is a balance of every genre done perfectly.

The soundtrack is also perfected. It makes you sing along to every song. James Gunn has perfected his GOTG trilogy and his time at marvel. Now he can venture to DC and perfect their universe.

There are no words to describe how this movie captures the meaning of family and friendship, they hit all the right boxes on how to end a fantastic trilogy to one of the best superhero teams ever created! Great job to James Gunn, the cast, and crew for making this one of my favorite MCU films to date. I never tears up that much before so whoever watches it next be prepared to bring tissues because this hits me in my feels. Stan Lee will be proud as he is watching this from above on how to bring a trilogy to life with a storyline that puts you the edge of your feet. I can't wait to see where we go from here knowing that its not the end for the GOTG!

Marvel Movie Worth Watching.

ChatGPT This is indeed one of the best Marvel movies in a long time. I used to think that Marvel had lost its creativity, but I was proven wrong after watching it in 3D. The movie was worth the watch. I appreciate how they focused on Rocket's story, which was filled with both action and emotion. It was interesting to see how Gamora no longer remembers Quill, leading to a new love story. This movie accurately portrays Rocket's life transformation and the pain experienced by such creatures. It feels like an emotional arrow piercing the heart, revealing the dark side of experiments. The film's relevance extends to real life as it showcases how experiments are conducted on these helpless creatures. Overall, as this is my first review, I can't say much, but I highly recommend you watch it and experience it for yourself. You won't be disappointed.

The way that this film handles Rocket's character is very touching and mostly well done. However, aside from that and a handful of other character moments, this film is a string of contrivances and conveniences.

One of the largest plot problems is the sidelining of Mantis' powers. There are quite a few roadblocks in this film that the Guardians have to scramble to overcome, which could have been entirely avoided had Mantis used her powers.

Much of the antagonists' failures are due to their own lack of foresight or lack of muscle, despite both enemy factions having essentially limitless recourses and competence at their disposal.

The plot is strung along via convenience and contrivance, where the Guardians either luck out entirely or the situations are simply shoehorned together.

Gamorrah's behavior and introduction into the film feel especially contrived considering what we know of her characterization from pre-2014 Guardians and rolling into that film, where she was arguably the most altruistic of the group.

The humor works in some places, but it suffers from an extreme over-reliance on "Drax dumb" based jokes, which were already wearing thin by Infinity War.

Perhaps the most frustrating part of this film was the use of humor to interrupt serious moments of peril or drama. The first two films balanced humor with drama much better. Due to the driving motive for the Guardians being so desperate and personal in this outing, the humor more often than not feels wholly out of place.

There are numerous other issues characterization and world building.

On a subjective level, the camera work was often distracting. There is a large amount of close up shots, sometimes coming in before any establishing shots, which makes much of the first act feel claustrophobic in a bad way. There is also what feels like random use of slow motion at times. There was also a lot of spinning. A distracting amount of spinning.

The sense of space generally felt off due to editing and shot compositions, as well as a large reliance on large scope computer generated rooms or environments enveloping the characters. This was a shock since Gunn's other works tend to be very cohesive and pleasant to watch.

The score was forgettable, not sure I remember any of it, aside from the one time the Guardians' theme was used.

Aside from some poignant exceptions, the soundtrack felt more obligatory than like the film needed ALL of the twenty something songs which play at every other scene. A far cry from their careful use in the first film.

The performances were all stellar, especially the villain and Rocket.

This film had a great core story to tell, but it got bungled. I am very saddened by this, as the Guardians had been mostly sublime to this point.

Third best Marvel project since Infinity War, just behind the Spider-Man films.

Sad.

In times where most heroes get turned into losers in order to introduce magically "empowered" Mary Sues, the Guardians of the Galaxy trilogy has shared a unique, well-crafted, powerful story with us, evolving its characters from losers or nobodies into unforgettable heroes, and for that I am deeply grateful. This movie specifically has delivered the best MCU film I have seen in a looong while and I doubt I'll ever care about any new MCU character the way I care about the Guardians of the Galaxy. From the bottom of my heart, thank you James Gunn! And thanks to everyone involved in creating and delivering the entire Guardians of the Galaxy trilogy.

I really can't think of a better title, but I will just say that this movie took me through quite the emotional journey. This movie is everything that the superhero genre has been trying to do for so long. Nobody can copy James Gunn's style of directing. I was on the verge of tears from sadness, and the movie actually brought me the tears with its laugh out loud funny comedy at times. I will really miss this group of ragtag heroes, especially Batista as Drax the Destroyer. I really don't want to say too much more about the movie other than that you will laugh, you will most likely cry, and you will have such a blast. The villain is possibly the most evil villain I have ever seen in a marvel movie, he has no remorse, no morals it seems, and has a god complex. Everybody acts their hearts out and plays their characters to perfection. I hope there will be some Guardians of the Galaxy spin-offs.

The introduction of Adam warlock feels a bit strange considering vision was kind of like who he was supposed to be. That's really the only thing that felt off, but the casting was great and the character was pretty cool and has some standout moments. There are some cute moments with some of the side characters and creatures, and I really had fun with this movie, so did my family. Take this review for what you will, I just can't expend the energy explaining how much I enjoyed the movie, but take my word for it, it's great! It's the best movie in this phase 4 of the MCU thus far.

As the last film of the Guardians trilogy GotG3 is the farewell that the team of crazy and equally loveable super heroes deserves. Zoe Saldana and Dave Bautista stated they are done with the MCU now, so the movie is also a farewell to them, especially Bautistas Drax is at his best in the trilogy. Even more prominently is the departure of director James Gunn from Marvel. If this were sports, his transfer to DC would be called a blockbuster deal because he is responsible for much of the best super hero content recently: The suicide squad, Peacemaker and Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3, that is an impressive track record in a struggling genre.

And GotG3 really is a very good movie, imo the best MCU-entry post Endgame. The Guardians always were the funny movies and unlike so many other Marvel movies that really struggle due to the need of shoving a quippy remark in every line, it works for the Guardians. Granted there are still one or two moments I wish would have been played out longer before the comic relief but overall that is not a huge deal. And the movie manages to combine good comedy with surprising darkness and emotionality. There is certainly no lack of that especially in Rocket's back story, which plays a significant role and is so well done. Despite being predictable at times it really got me. It says a lot about the MCU that the movie with the music-addict, the walking tree and the talking racoon is the one that finally works on the emotional level again. The characters are handled very well and get nice developments. I already mentioned Drax and Rocket who is really the heart of the movie but it is also true for the others, Groot and Mantis especially. Star-Lord almost feels like playing second fiddle after being the focus of the previous movies but he and most others still end up making a journey we did not know we wanted but needed.

On the villain side we have Adam Warlock who feels a bit tacked on tbh. His introduction is very strong but after that it at times seems like he is only in it because they teased him in GotG2. It does not really bother me but he is not the movie's strong suit either especially when compared to the other villain. Because the high evolutionary is amazing. His utopian motivation is not revolutionary for a movie-villain but that doesn't make it bad. He is so despicable, has just the right amount of power and is beautifully played by Chukwudi Iwuji. Kick the dog is a classic writing advice and means to let the villain do something that will immediately make everyone in the audience dislike him and this technique works here, you just hate this guy, without it turning completely ridiculous and unreasonable. The best MCU villain since Thanos.

Aside from that the CGI looks good and the soundtrack once again is a big strength of the Guardians movies. The story is not particularly intricate, McGuffin quests play a significant role but they set the ground for the interactions between and development of the characters, which works and mostly carries the movie. The length is not a problem, I am fully on board with seeing those flawed but loveable characters interact for 150 minutes, it never felt stretched for me. The film largely stands on its own and is not occupied with setting up dozens of storylines for the MCU at large, which helps the individual movie a lot. Lastly I want to say that the movie is helped by the fact that it is the last of the trilogy, so the characters could die, making several scenes a lot more tense.

Overall a really strong movie that serves as a reminder of better MCU-times. The question is whether it signals a return to strength for Marvel or whether it will prove to be a final and wonderful goodbye for the MCUs golden era.

At their base of Knowhere, the Guardians of the Galaxy consisting of Peter Qull/Star-Lord (Chris Pratt), Drax (Dave Bautista), Nebula (Karen Gillan), Peter's half-sister Mantis (Pom Klementieff), Groot (Vin Diesel) and Rocket (Bradley Cooper) continue their operations as ragtag adventurers and defenders as Peter still struggles with depression and alcoholism as he struggles to accept the Gamora (Zoe Saldana) loved is gone while the one who exists is an entirely different person who no longer loves him. When artificial being Adam Warlock (Will Poulter) attacks nowhere and sets his sights on Rocket, the Guardians barely manage to hold him off but in the end win but not before Rocket suffers heavy injuries. In their attempt to revive Rocket they discover a killswitch has been installed along with all the augmentations that have been done to him, and in order to save Rocket they must find an override key for the Killswitch which leads the group through Rocket's tortured past at the hands of the cruel High Evolutionary (Chukwudi Iwuji) who seeks to create the "perfect" being through horrific experiments.

The Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 is the long awaited and in development third entry in the James Gunn helmed series of MCU films. It's certainly been a long road to this follow-up as its been 10 years since the last Standalone Guardians film even though the Guardians themselves have been continually present in the MCU (for better or worse). There was even doubt that the third entry would even be made as Gunn found himself fired by Disney due to commentators circulating old twitter jokes from Gunn's timeline on Twitter which prompted a visceral reaction from fans and creatives in the industry and lead to Gun being hired by Warner Bros. For The Suicide Squad and Disney to humble themselves and ask Gunn to come back for what will be his final step in the MCU as he takes control of Warner Bros.' DCEU (good luck with that, you're gonna need it). While I still maintain my favorite entry in the series is the second one, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 scores the same genuine heart and soul we saw in the prior entries, even if it is burdened by some plot cleanup of MCU plot points.

Much like prior entries, the soundtrack does a great job of setting the mood and tone for the story, but in this case in a decidedly different way. Unlike Vol. 1 or 2 where they were more upbeat songs set to action beats, Vol.3 opens with a haunting acoustic cover of Creep by Radiohead as we follow Rocket who is the primary focus this time around with Peter Quill more of a supporting element this time around. While Rocket's tortured past had been hinted at in the prior installments, this is where those little hints come full circle as we dive deep into Rocket's backstory and dive into the lingering trauma that has haunted Rocket but he's hidden behind a cynical and snarky demeanor. There's been some energized discussion over the "experiment" scenes in the film and while they aren't as explicitly shown as certain other films that cover this material, the flashbacks detailing Rocket's story and the makeshift family he had with other experiments like himself is low key disturbing in its implications especially in how most of the worst parts are implied or off screen with a particularly haunting moment where Rocket's first word is revealed to be "hurts". The scenes in these flashbacks work twofold because not only does it give massive insight to Rocket's character and play for heartbreaking tragedy, but it also gives us a fantastically despicable villain in Chukwudi Iwuji's High Evolutionary. The High Evolutionary is probably the best villain we've seen in this series eclipsing the still very impressive Kurt Russell portrayed Ego, but where Ego you could see had some level of affinity for Peter (even if it was revealed to be narcissistic in nature with horrifying undertones) there is no such pretense of that here as the High Evolutionary shows himself to be a twisted and casually cruel with no empathy, remorse, or shame as he mutilates and exterminates living things in search of the nebulously defined "perfection" that he seeks to find. His relationship with Rocket is beautifully done the High Evolutionary considers Rocket a failed experiment, and yet it was one the managed to outsmart him and became a source of obsession for the High Evolutionary because he can't get around the fact that something he created was able to best him and it really makes you want to see his downfall as a villain.

Of course Rocket's story is only part of the film with the secondary plot covering Peter Quill overcoming his depression and alcoholism as he's still reeling from the loss of Gamora during Infinity War. This is where I feel Gunn was given a bit of a "when life gives you lemons situation" because prior to Infinity War the Guardians movies were relatively self-contained in the MCU and when time came to bring Thanos center stage the Guardians were moved more towards the center for event films and cameos where you could tell they weren't written by Gunn and we got several factors like Peter dooming the universe or Gamora's death and her coming back as a hardened version of herself who was barely away from Thanos and effectively made the character as we knew her no longer exist. Here and to a lesser extent the Christmas special, it feels like Gunn is trying to pull away from the MCU a little bit and bring these characters back to where they were and this even comes down to the fact there's no mention of their very brief association with Thor (the less said about that the better). While Gunn does use the pieces he's been given quite well in terms of where Peter and Gamora now stand with Peter still loving someone who no longer exists and Gamora now considerably hardened with little idea who Peter is and even less desire to care, this is one of those elements that is weighted down by the fact Gamora is now so heavily tied in with major events in the MCU that it hampers the standalone appeal to a degree. But in spite of this (and the requisite MCU threads and teases) Gunn does a good job coalescing all these elements into a story about trauma and overcoming it and there is a solid note of finality established so we and Gunn feel like we're saying goodbye to these characters. While I sincerely doubt this is the last we'll see of the Guardians, this is for all intents and purposes the final chapter on Gunn's Guardians.

While Vol.3 isn't the best of the series due to its weighty ties to MCU lore, it's a solid culmination of everything we've been through with the Guardians and a harrowing story with a strong emotional core and a truly despicable villain. There's also a solid feeling of saying goodbye to these characters and it'll be a satisfying sendoff for those who've followed this crew.

Note: While the animal abuse isn't massively explicit in terms of what is shown, it is heavily implied. In terms of severity: Think less Bambi and more Plague Dogs or Watership Down.

Wow. Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 came at the perfect time. Just when I, and many others, had lost faith in the MCU, James Gunn and his merry band of misfits come back to remind us why so many of us fell in love with the franchise in the first place.

It's the characters, stupid. The Guardians of the Galaxy feel like the most fleshed out, genuine, complicated super hero team in existence; the interpersonal relations between the members, their personal struggles, quirks, perspectives and so on are so well developed, I can imagine fan fiction for these people for years to come. In contrast, even with comparatively good Marvel films of late (like Black Panther or Dr. Strange) I can't genuinely tell you anything about most of the characters in those films. Not with the Guardians.

Every character gets amazing moments and I felt, goes in a sensible direction. I can easily write and essay on each one of them, what motivates them, why they act the way they do, what they mean to the team; it's not a flex on my part, it's the quality of the writing and performances.

Speaking of which, there are some truly great ones here and from places I didn't expect. Chukwudi Iwuji as the High Evolutionary was FANTASTIC. I love that we didn't get a sympathetic villain or one the film insists we "understand." No, he's just maniacally evil and selfish, and it's nice when a movie gives you a villain who seems powerful and you really want to see get defeated.

This movie reminds you why Chris Pratt is a beloved movie star; he exudes the confidence and swagger of action heroes from the past, which was refreshing. Dave Bautista and Pom Klementieff's Drax and Mantis continue with their incredible chemistry and of course, as a result of excellent make up and costuming, literally disappear into their characters. Karen Gillan's accent was a bit wonky to start, but I felt she gave a truly fantastic performance with this one. Nebula is such a cool and lovable character. Bradley Cooper gets very emotional as Rocket in this one (whom the film basically centres around) and I'm happy he did such an amazing job. Even Zoe Saldana's return as Gomorrah (which I didn't really like the idea of initially, since it continues the trend of death meaning nothing in the MCU), was handled brilliantly. I loved her performance and what they ultimately did with her character vis a vis the team and Peter Quill in particular.

In terms of action, GOTG 3 is surprisingly sparse with it and despite the long 2 1/2 hr run time, it didn't really bother me. The film is so well paced, there's so much going on, that I barely noticed. But when the action scenes happen, oh man, are they incredible. There's one extended fight sequence towards the end that was honestly the best I've seen from the MCU in a long time and so freakin fun and well shot. Another point; this movie doesn't feel like a Disney film, unlike so many other MCU instalments. There's blood, there's death. This movie gets really dark and violent at times and it adds to the stakes.

But the best thing about this movie is how delightfully weird and off kilter it is. This movie gives us an organic space ship, golden super powered people, a counter Earth with anthropomorphized animals, weird seedy animal experimentation, a telekinetic Russian space dog...you get the feeling watching this movie that Gunn had a lot of creative control and wasn't afraid to just go weird with it.

If I had any issues, I'd say the editing is a little bizarre at times and there's one scene towards the end that just felt jarring and poorly cut, but it's a minor issue throughout the whole movie. I also loved Will Poulter as Adam Warlock, and what they did with the character (making him an uber powerful, lovable doofus), but I wished he had more screen time and bigger role in the plot.

Aside from that, I could keep gushing about this movie. From the music to the set design to the incredibly dark, emotional flashbacks that had more than a few fully grown people tearing up in my cinema to the beautiful theme of broken people finding salvation with kindness and love, this is just an excellent movie. So long Guardians, it's be great.

First Guardians of the Galaxy was really the best of the 3. Second one wasn't so bad but this 3rd Guardians of the Galaxy is so bad, I wanted to leave just 10 minutes into the movie. The dialogues were so terrible, it bordered on lame and "WTF!" The story line was ok but still not enough for me to give this movie a higher rating.

Normally, I would tell people to wait for the movie to be shown on Disney+ or Netflix or wherever if I think the movie is not worth watching in theaters. In this case, I wouldn't recommend watching this movie in theaters or even on Disney+. It's just not worth it! Go watch some other movies.

Marvel hasn't put out a quality movie since avengers endgame. For many people including myself, this was the chance I was going to give marvel before I stopped seeing their movies altogether.

GOTG3 brought back all the things that made it a game changer for the MCU. Music, actually good humor that isn't forced, and lots of color. The story was mostly good but the villain left something to be desired. Unlike Thanos, this villain's antics and motivators were weakly supported. There were definitely clunky parts but overall it was a GOOD movie. Be warned, some of it may have you crying in da club.

Though a bit bloated and overstuffed with explosion-laden, standard-issue action sequences we've seen in dozens of superhero movies, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 is also an exhilarating, consistently funny, big-hearted adventure that packs a surprising emotional wallop. The runtime of 150 minutes was a bit long top, but hey we got to see the backstory of Rocket, and damn that was emotional on many occasions.

The finale of one of the most loved group of funny, misfit heroes in Marvel Universe bids a perfect farewell to it's audience and James Gunn left no stone unturned to make sure that Vol 3 was full of action, comedy and humour. Gunn has built up all kinds of profound interpersonal connections between this sizable ensemble over three movies, and in Vol. 3, he delights in indulging them, digging into all of the ways of this family making a farewell not only for the audience but also for its characters.

My Rating : 8/10.

I don't get it. Adam Warlock arc to me feels very forced, but other than that everything are amazing; the plot, writing, message and moral of the story, they're all are top notch. And also they don't use that nanotech bullcr**p that Marvel always uses for the past couple of century, and they're the one that started it. I definitely think that that is a conscious decision by James Gunn from listening to the fan on what doesn't work and what does.

Another thing that I hate is that apparently this movie is a continuation of the Christmas special, I didn't watch it so I was kinda left behind for the first few minutes, but then after that I just learn to accept it without asking too many questions.

But other than all of that, definitely an amazing trilogy ending.

This certainly was fun to watch. I noticed that I was actually smiling continuously at the end portion not because jokes were there but I was really enjoying it.

It has good portion of comedy, though some of it didn't land, but all jokes never land, do they? Appreciable on that end.

The animation and action scenes were really nicely done. Ok, I will say this, there is a one shot scene which makes it better. Every character is clearly portrayed.

The background music on many portions were awesome. Really makes you feel what the character is feeling.

The problematic elements for me were jokes not landing. Otherwise awesome.

Y'all must have watched a different movie than me. This is the worst Marvel in the last ten years in my opinion. Little to no plot/story, dumb villains, bad costumes, cheesy lines, unholy amount of plotholes, pure CGI feast... The only good thing in that movie was the cinematography, that's it. I questioned my status as a GotG fan and asked myself several times why I have to go through this "movie". Come on. Nothing made even slightly sense and the characters get weirder and worse. It just felt like a Disney movie the whole time but like a Disney movie where Walt Disney smoked crack and got blackout drunk before he wrote the script. It was even worse than Multiverse of Madness and Thor Love & Thunder and I thought thats's impossible. Just imagine the bad plot and nonsense from MoM combined withe cornyness and cringe of Love & Thunder and voilà that's GotG 3. It doesn't have the charm of the old GotG movies and the music was not that important anymore. Total waste of money and time.

Most definitely one of the top 10 saddest movies EVER (if you're into Marvel and and Guardians of the Galaxy)!! My caption isn't a spoiler since most Marvel cap out at 3, but it's upsetting nonetheless.

I love how Rocket is the main focus but because of the antics the guardians get up to, it's forgettable, and yet it's still carried on throughout the entire movie, even after certain events take place.

The end was absolutely devastating. I can say with confidence this movie is predictable and absolutely not all at once. I think a big factor of the sadness this movie gives me is knowing that it's the end. Not the end of the guardians, but the end of an era of the guardians of the Galaxy.

No, they're not gone, and we will surely see them in our movies, as it always is with Marvel movies. That said, it is still absolutely abhorrently sorrowful and I still feel like crying a day later.

100% recommend, but it's not all goofs like the rest of the movies. I saw a lot of people complaining about the fact that it's not funny, but what's funny is the fact that it wasn't meant to be. This movie touched on some of the deeper, edgier, and overall more depressing topics; and I think that's what this series so to speak needed. This movie saved marvel, 2023. Without it, I would be losing all hope the rest of the marvel movies been good.

Usually trilogies go first one being the best second one is the runner and third is just ok.

Not in this case guardians of galaxy 3 is as good as first one if not a little better just a little different story line.

Especially Rocket story it does touch your soul they made the scenes really deep.

Dave Bautista ( Drax) he played excellent, especially as a dad !

Peter as always good very charismatic funny and excellent play.

Nebula was excellent you can understand how much she needed a family and how much she was fit for a family

Gamora to be honest I had feelings sometimes that she was somebody extra in the movie that doesn't need to be in.

Overall 8.7 out of 10.

Guardians of the Galaxy VOL.3 is an almost perfect end to an incredible Marvel Trilogy even if never quite reaches the heights of the first film in the franchise but is undoubtedly better than the second installment.

The story is well written and well paced and is overflowing with humour, heart and emotions. The characters are well written and have great arcs. Rocket was the shining star. Bradley Cooper did a great job and his arc is one of the best in the MCU.

The action sequences are mostly well choreographed though much of the work was put into the story and the characters which is a great thing tbh.

Also the movie is visually stunning with bright and bold color choices and the CGI is much better than a lot of the recent Marvel releases.

Despite being 2 and a half hours long it never feels dragged or slow even for a second and at the end of the day it all feels earned. Definitely check it out.

Nothing to not like about this. Just the most unashamedly fun you can have at the theather. A sensorial overload of colour, space tecnology, crazy fighting sequences and mind-boggling set pieces. A visual wonder of course and perhaps the most pleasing movie to watch out of the trilogy.

If there's someone who knows what their doing it is James Gunn. It's a shame that the big Marvel corporate is losing one of its brightest minds. To take a bunch of crazy, stupid and fun dark horses and turn them into the face of one of the biggest franchises on earth it's truly a remarkable achievement. I only see a big light in front of James Gunn career.

You can argue that it drags for a bit, that it takes a lot of paths that the previous movies did and that some characters might feel a little left behind, but I find it really hard for you to not give credit to this man for making movies that feel so personal and detached from the formulaic crap that we've been recieving for quite some years now. The guardians have their great emotional farewell and nobody feels like it's just another side character.

And yes, maybe the real message behind all of this crazy space trilogy is that what matters at the end of the day is that you have your friends around you and that you respect the animals, but what's the matter with that really?

I love the guardians and I love James Gunn, and for me they belong to their singular universe where there isn't any multiverse/cameo/greedy noise behind it.

This was not a perfect movie. But goodness, did it come close. Absolutely the best entry into the MCU since Endgame, and one of the best ever. Excellent screenplay, great individual performances and a top-notch return to the humor that made this franchise a hit in the first place.

But of all the things this movie did well, the most significant to me was the pure emotion, the depth of feeling. It has been some time since I have seen a movie of any genre so accurately tap into and display the range of human emotion that this did. The pain, the relief, the loss, the exuberant joy - all portrayed so well I could not help but feel it too. This movie entertained me, yes. But it made me feel human. And they did it with aliens, raccoons, and cyborgs. Fantastic stuff.

Because even if they end up making another Guardians of the Galaxy movie, it just won't be the same so this will forever be a trilogy for me, and many others I'm sure. Great heartfelt story, excellent directing, acting performances on point, and MCU level special effects are just mmmmwah (chef's kiss). I do feel like MCU movies post Endgame are lacking compared to the hay days of Marvel but this one is way above the rest and managed to re-capture that old je-ne-sais-quoi that just works. We can but only hope they keep going that way (I'm not super hopeful though). But whether you're an MCU fan or not, I still highly recommend this one!

Be under no illusion this film is not comparable to the other Guardians of the Galaxy movies. The last time I was this traumatised by a film was probably when watching Watership Down (which I have seen a few times over the years but not in the last 15). Rocket's back story is counter balanced with the dedication shown to him by his friends. I give it an 8 on the basis that the music is the weakest selection in any Guardians film and it would have been interesting to see more of Warlock. Sci-Fi, adventure, humour, redemption and heart break (so much!) all feature, but rest assured I will never again watch this film.

In the final part of the trilogy, the world - or at least "one" world - needs to be saved by the Guardians of the Galaxy while the group deals with its own internal issues. The premise without much complexity is common to hero movies, including good hero movies, as were volumes 1 and 2 of this series, and as is this Volume 3. The trilogy, since its inception, has highlighted the right mix between action and comedy, with a thin dose of drama to not make a fantasy involving a talking raccoon too silly. It was working very well. But the frustration with the hero movies of recent years - mainly the result of too many releases and little creativity in scripts underestimating the intelligence and patience of the public - ended up causing apprehension about Guardians 3. In the end, the action scenes seem more of the same - not many, to a remarkable extent. Negative points are also the initial 30min a little dragged and a poorly worked transformation that the "new" Gamora goes through. All this, however, becomes less important in the face of the best of the film, which comes from the unexpected: Rocket's touching origin, the foundation of the plot. Yes, it's the exciting scenes in the story of a raccoon that make Guardians 3 more than a good action movie: in addition to the already expected good comic footprint, there's a great drama, which gave a surprisingly positive density to this farewell... although the post-credits scenes may suggest what they suggest.

James Gunn hits the ball out of the park with his 3rd and last installment of the GOTG3. What an Emotional ride it has been. From start till end this film has loads of emotional aspects and that's the perfect way to say goodbye to all the fans. This is how a marvel movie should be. Well Guardians hasn't appreciated much in the mcu but after watching this film marvel fans won't forget the team of guardians. We all know james gunn always trying something new whether it's a character or it's relatable to the story. But this time he had chose the back story of rocket which is just way beyond hard hitting. And the way director has shown in the film is just perfect. I mean it's 2hr 30 mins movie but you don't even blink when you'll watch the film that's what this film does to you. Every character whether in lead or supporting does a perfect job and has the time to shine. Music is the soul whenever we talk about GOTG. And this film also has music that suits to the situation. Screenplay, VFX and conversation between the lead characters is top notch. Everyone know james gunn will not return after this but still he gave us the perfect gift to remember him. One of the best film in the trilogy don't miss this....

After enjoying Guardians part 1 and 2 we were looking forward to this and anticipated a similar experience. So much of this movie depicts animal cruelty that my kids (middle school age) were both reduced to tears. I don't have any issues with telling Rocket's story but it would have been nice to have a heads up. The violence was a lot more explicit overall than in the first two movies. We all left a bit traumatized, to be honest.

Also, Gamora's storyline was kind of pointless. The scenes she was in just ended up being a frustrating waste of time. I liked her character a lot in the first two movies - this is nothing to do with the actor - the writing for her was just kind of pointless in this one.

I have given 10 out of 10 stars to Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 and I want to share my spoiler-free positive review with you. This is the third and final installment of the Guardians of the Galaxy trilogy, written and directed by James Gunn, and it is a spectacular conclusion to the story of the lovable misfits who save the galaxy.

The film picks up after the events of Avengers: Endgame and Thor: Love and Thunder, with the Guardians still coping with the loss of Gamora and trying to find their place in a post-Thanos universe. They are also faced with a new threat: Adam Warlock, a powerful being created by the Sovereign to destroy them. Meanwhile, Rocket's past comes back to haunt him when he learns that he is not the only one of his kind, and that his creator, the High Evolutionary, has sinister plans for him and his fellow experiments.

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 is a thrilling, hilarious, emotional, and satisfying film that delivers on all fronts. The action sequences are stunning and inventive, the humor is sharp and witty, the characters are well-developed and relatable, and the themes are resonant and meaningful. The film also pays homage to the previous films in the series and ties up all the loose ends in a satisfying way. The cast is phenomenal, with Chris Pratt, Zoe Saldana, Dave Bautista, Karen Gillan, Pom Klementieff, Vin Diesel, Bradley Cooper, Will Poulter, Sean Gunn, Chukwudi Iwuji, Linda Cardellini, Nathan Fillion, and Sylvester Stallone all giving memorable performances. The film also features some surprising cameos and references that will delight fans of the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 is a must-see film for anyone who loves sci-fi, comedy, adventure, or just good cinema. It is one of the best films of 2023 and one of the best films in the MCU. It is a fitting farewell to the Guardians of the Galaxy and a testament to James Gunn's vision and talent. I highly recommend it to everyone who wants to have a blast at the movies.

At first I was kinda like meh, but as the movie progresses it gets SO good. I cried, laughed, smiled and pleasantly enjoyed it. Definitely not what I was expecting at all, and in a good way! Marvel movies get repetitive and kinda boring, but this movie was something so unexpected and so enjoyable. It has some really heartbreaking scenes and an overall sad theme but I love how it all comes together in the end. The sound track was awesome, thoroughly enjoyed it. Not sure if there will be a fourth one with this ending, but I'm always down to watch the Guardians of the Galaxy! Hoping that Gamora will join the Guardians again!

It was one of the greatest marvel movies and the greatest in the last four years, to feel the characters was easy and really emotional witch makes it a positive point for the movie.

Actually we saw both sides of story. Inside the GOTG and how important and hard was the problem, at some moments it was really stressful combined with emotional witch is rare but essential.

This movie proved that the third sequel can be the best one.

Actors played excellent and dialogues were meaningful performed in right times.

This movie is artistic and moneymaker at the same time And one more thing about it is how good were grand stages and battle scene Altogether it was a great movie.

Could it be the end .. the clip at the very end gives me Hope there'll be another one . I love guardians of the galaxy. Great characters, humour and soundtrack. Have loved all three but this one just slightly better . Rockets story is great and shows why friendship is so important to him. I did get upset twice during the film which my friend said to expect . Love will poulters character and hope if there's a no 4 he will be in it . Myself and my grandson were fixed to it . Never once checking how long is left or getting voted

It's a fabulous watch and I'm sure any fans of marvel will marvel at this one.

I am so glad James Gunn was given the chance to make the GOTG trilogy because he made me love the guardians when I first thought it was "stupid" of Marvel to make a movie involving a talking raccoon and tree. My 14 year old self thought it had no shot at being successful. I was wrong.

Guardians of The Galaxy 3 is a beautiful and perfect ending to the trilogy. Each and every character has their arc completed in an amazing way. The film is truly unique and surprising pretty dark at times, something Marvel rarely does. The CGI is great and a joy to watch. Watching in IMAX was great and I want to see it again to experience it all over.

This is one of Marvel's best films and definitely has its own vibe and differs itself from all the other marvel movies, even the other Guardian movies. It's dark and sad at times but still finds perfect moments to input that comedy we all know and love from the GOTG.

Take notes Marvel.

Do yourself a favor. Wait for this to stream on Disney+ if you're still a subscriber. That way when you're finished watching after 30 minutes, you will be okay with stopping it in the privacy of your own home and won't have to trip over people to walk out of it in a theater.

Easily this film is darkest and most discombobulated story in the franchise. There were so many times that I wanted to walk out but I didn't because of how much money we had spent to go to this garbage film. Will be the last Marvel film I ever waste time and money on in the theaters. I never write reviews for any movies, but had to for this one in hopes of saving someone somewhere their time and money.

This film was the most magical experience I've had at any film since Endgame. There's only two things I would change about the movie but neither of them are worth changing, only reason it's not a perfect 10 for me, definitely a 9.8/10. One is where a certain pg-13 line goes in the film and I feel like it would've been funnier elsewhere! The other is the lack of a certain character's presence in the film but that's the point of the whole movie lol.

Go see it if you haven't. It's leagues away from the last phase of the MCU in the best way possible, proving that people aren't experiencing superhero fatigue - Marvel-Disney have just been force feeding us crappy films for the sake of it.

The soundtrack is top tier, second only to Guardians 1.

Thank you James Gunn. This was a treasure.

Now please bring back Henry Cavill :D.

Guardians of the Galaxy 3 is a film that is the conclusion of one of the most vivid and memorable Marvel franchises. Director James Gunn not only retains his recognizable own style, which we love, but also reveals new facets of the world that he created back in 2014, showing the world his first creation for Marvel.

In the film, we see how Peter Quill and his team face new challenges and obstacles that force them to rethink their relationship with each other. If the last two parts of the franchise focused mainly on the team leader Peter, then the third story perfectly shows the arc of the formation of the Rocket. The character has become the soul of this film, constant flashbacks reveal the Rocket to the viewer from a new side. Gunn tells us after the fact why we know the hero the way he is. And it turns out that the Rocket has a rich and difficult past. The director's skillful moves make us rethink this character, empathize with him in a completely different way, understand why he became the person we saw him in the first two pictures of the series. It is perfectly clear that for the creators and Gunn in particular, the raccoon is not just part of a heroic team. Rocket is one of the key heroes for all of them, about whose difficult fate the guys wanted to tell so much. Scenes from the past are imbued with sincerity and beauty, sadness and warmth. The rocket is the decoration of the third film, the central character. However, this does not mean that the rest of the characters are ignored. The creators are ready to tell about them, completing the arches of each hero properly. We see how they prioritize and choose their paths, and the viewer is full of understanding that we will never forget these heroes and their adventures.

The picture is full of storylines, sometimes it seems that a couple of them does not make sense at all. In my opinion, the appearance of Adam Warlock here is not particularly conditioned by anything. The character was little revealed, in the plot I would not say that he played an important role. I liked the villain the Supreme Evolutionist performed by Chukudi Iwuji. The Guards' opponent turned out to be strong and motivated. He was much better suited for the plot and was more convincing than the recently available Kang from Ant-Man 3.

And of course, "Guardians of the Galaxy 3" would not be the Guardians that the viewer loves and waits for without outstanding action on the screen. The picture, as always with James Gunn, is rich, bright, sometimes funny, and sometimes sad. But it's still the same recognizable Gunn at the helm of the ship, which for the last time for Marvel demonstrates its full potential, sending viewers on an unprecedented adventure across the Galaxy.

The actors are on top again. Chris Pratt, Karen Gillan, Pom Klementieff, Dave Batista, Zoe Saldana, Vin Diesel, Bradley Cooper, Sean Gunn - thank you for your work.

Guardians of the Galaxy 3 is a movie that cannot be missed. This is a bright, memorable and touching film. The picture not only completes one of the most interesting Marvel franchises, but also shows how important it is to preserve your style and uniqueness in cinema. And the heroes will forever remain in our hearts, memorable, unique and so beloved.

9 out of 10.

The entire movie is the example of perfection. From the start to the end evry scene is full of emotion, be it happiness, sadness, or a wholesome moment. I had tears in my eyes throughout the movie, i had a smile on my face and i was cheering every 10 secs. This marvelous piece of motion picture is one of the bestest marvel has ever produced, this is how you end a trilogy, a movie filled with emotions. Every second had a meaning of its own, no moment is present except that it contributes to the greatness of this mindblowing work.

The action sequences have a significance of their own, the camera work, the action choreography, the scene itself and the acting all top teir.

The story makes sense, every event makes sense, all the chafacters make sense, the charcter devolopement is great, the ending is meaningful. Thats 10/10 writing adn directing for ya.

This movie is the example of top tier marvel and a proof that marvel is still alive, the movies and their writing just need a bit of thought and you end up with a masterpiece like this.

The story plays out following the events of the previous GOTG movie appearances where Peter Quill now continues to wallow in pity following the loss of Gamora. He only shakes away from this to take on a mission to save his friend Rocket following a near fatal attack from a newcomer looking to abduct Rocket.

This is a well acted visually incredible movie with brilliant action, set pieces, hits both many humorous and emotional notes over and over again but somehow falls a little flat.

I did enjoy this movie very much but I think the premise of the story just did not sit quite right (with previous knowledge of the MCU). In this movie we are shown (through flashbacks) that Rocket is a creature of immense intellect and intellect that goes beyond genius (almost a superpower), which maybe I'm wrong but I do not remember being a thing in any of the previous movies. Intelligent, capable, street smart, wise cracking yes, but genius, not sure. But it's this premise that the entire story sits upon.

Likewise in this movie we are introduced to the Warlock who feels superfluous to the story and most probably has only been shoehorned in for future instalments or alternative MCU movies.

Whilst the movie feels more 'epic' than volumes 1 and 2 it is not as good and does not have a soundtrack anywhere near as good. It's definitely one of the better post Thanos MCU offerings and probably sits just in the upper half of all the MCU but I don't think it's one of the hits.

In summary it's a good entry to the MCU and a solid 3rd outing for GOTG but isn't one of the greats.

Rating: 8.0 Overall, a good end to the trilogy that has become a staple in the MCU as James Gunn uses tone/writing/visual effects to build off his previous comedic movies while also creating what might be the saddest/most touching Marvel movie (mainly through the backstory/writing of Rocket), but the movie does fall under the trap many Marvel movies follow as it is a bit too restricted by the predictable MCU boilerplate to be more profound that it is capable of being.

Very Good Direction (This movie really shows how comfortable Gunn is at guiding ensemble casts through super hero epics as he pulls from experience to drive the story forward; Gunn also really shows his ability to tell a heartbreaking story by weaving past elements to fuel the present), Pretty Good to Good Acting (Good from Chris Pratt (Really builds off his experience as the leader of the group as he has his signature charm while showcasing more of his dramatic chops), Pretty Good to Good from Zoe Saldana (Her character is more restricted/rigged this time so she can't really show too much emotion, but she does a good job with what she was given), Pretty Good to Good from Dave Bautista, Pretty Good to Good from Karen Gillan, Good from Pom Klementieff, Good from Vin Diesel, Great from Bradley Cooper (Really shows a range of emotions through this vocal performance and displays why he is the real protagonist of the movie), Pretty Good from Sean Gunn, Decent to Pretty Good from Chukwudi Iwuji (His performance was a bit too over-the-top for me but he definitely shows some good moments (its just he went from 0 to 100 way too often); I also think his character was pretty shallowly written as his backstory/motive is not really addressed that well), Decent to Pretty Good from Will Poulter (He was fine with the role he was given, its just I do not think his character was written that well), Good from Sylvester Stallone (That's because he's Sly Stallone, the man), Pretty Good from the rest of the cast), Good Story (Does a great job at concluding the trilogy by closing up the lose-ends of many of the characters; the overall plot was well written and entertaining to watch (though it could have been cut just a little bit); the Rocket backstory was incredibly touching and really showed the trauma Rocket had to go through throughout his whole life (even though it could be argued it is a bit simple and relies on the cute animal trope (something I am able to move past given how moving it is)); the character writing for the villains was not the best because it really does not go into their backstory (so it makes it harder to believe their plight); the movie still does follow a lot of the same marvel trope that hold it back a bit), Good Screenplay (The dialog feels very similar to other movies in the trilogy as it is witty, funny, and touching; the symbolism of the movie is incredibly profound as it really looks into the effects friendships and family have on people (especially with how rigid Rocket is to opening up, the importance of family for Quill, and why Quill is trying to get Gamora back); the foreshadowing was kind a setback in the movie as it is just pretty predictable overall in how safe they go about the movie (I would have liked it to be a bit more depressing/dark to be more profound); still has very Marvel elements to the screenplay that restrict if from going above and beyond), Good Score/Very Good Soundtrack (while there wasn't a consistent theme as in the other movies, I still liked the song selection (like Creep and Dog Days Are Over)), Very Good Cinematography (Really enjoyed the 360/wide-angle style cinematography in the fight scenes (especially the hallway scene)), Very Good Sound, Very Good Editing, Great Visual Effects (Used CGI very well to help tell the story and make the fights entertaining), Good Production Design, Very Good Makeup, Very Good Costumes, Plot Structure was good for the most part as all the major points were laid out nicely (but there was a bit too much plot that was not that necessary (like 10-15 minutes could have been cut)); the narrative style of weaving between the past and the present was well done as it helped make Rocket a more multidimensional character, Pacing was good for the most part as it stayed a steady pace for most of the movie up until the end (the ending felt incredibly rushed at how abrupt it was (which kinda hurt considering it was meant to wrap up all the storylines for the Guardians)), Climax was entertaining and fun to watch but still showed many signs of following the Marvel formula (though there was some James Gunn touches on it that made it feel somewhat unique), Tone was established very well throughout the movie as it blends the sadder/dramatic parts very well with the more traditional lighthearted/funny moments to show how this installment continues where the previous installments left off while still being unique in its own-right; there still was some signs of it following the Marvel tone, The movie does a good job in helping provide more context to some of the the characters in the previous films (like Rocket) as the backstory presented shows why some of the characters acted in the way they did in the first two installments; this by far was the saddest MCU movie (mainly because of the character writing/backstory of Rocket)

Excelent movie, it deliveres what it needs to deliver. Nobody expects a Marvel movie to be the best one ever on history, and even so, this movie manages to be great for what it is, with funny characters and comments, marbelous soundtrack (I mean, WHAT a soundtrack), touching scenes and character backround (very crude at times, it impressed me that I was crying all throughout the movie) and good animation. The best of the 3 so far, and the best one I've seen by this studio (though I must admit I haven't seen a lot).

Couldn't agree more with the person that said, and I quote, "a scene between an intelligent raccoon, a rabit with artificial legs, a walrus with wheels and an otter with metal arms made me cry".

The Guardians of the Galaxy franchise has always been a thrilling ride, filled with quirky humor, lovable characters, and stunning visuals. Unfortunately, "Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3" stumbles and falls short of its predecessors, delivering a muddled and poorly executed script that may only appeal to the youngest of viewers. Ultimately, "Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3" is a disappointing misfire, offering little more than surface-level enjoyment for kids who aren't as invested in the narrative. It's a far cry from the previous installments, which managed to strike a balance between lighthearted fun and compelling storytelling.

This will be short and unfair to the value to the greatness of the guardians of the galaxy i mean it had it all the heroism the reality with it's ups and downs the human nature and the alien Sci-fi it suited the ages it contained the strong scenes with the light ones I'll say it disliking the trilogy and this movie especially will need u have such low taste and a broken role to the cinematic Fandom....... I Salute the guardians of the galaxy vol.3 the movie that showed the original roots of the MCU for a while now it gave the characters it's worth of the writing, the events the rightfull amount of time and most importantly the presence of justice and fan-service in the plot was just.

GOTG 3 is a good movie and a solid conclusion to the trilogy. The film deals with the team fighting to save one of their own from an insane scientist who does genetic experiments on animals in order to create a perfect utopia. The film asks what provides the higher quality of life for civilization...an abuser who enables or a community who struggles through adversity to form a common bond? The film has great action, cool designs, funny moments, and some genuine tragic elements that help have a cathartic experience. One hopes that this isn't the end for GOTG but if it is - they left if off on a great note.

Honestly, this movie has it all. It's funny, it's exciting, it's original, and it's very informative. The worst thing I could say about this movie, or actually the only bad thing I can say about it is the post credit trailer sucked. Don't waste your time waiting for it. Just read about it. This may actually be the best movie I have seen in the last five years. Usually I watch 99% of the movies streaming at home but this was well worth any cost of any ticket. I encourage you to run not walk to see this film. I would also encourage you to watch the previous movie, and the last avengers movie. If you do your homework, it will be well worth it.

For a long time I have understood the frustration of many marvel fans as the quality has been diminishing. But fear not! This movie is an absolute masterpiece. Amazing depth, story and a vast array of action that will make the movie length fly by! It's a jungle of emotions and creativity. If you loved the originals and follow the Guardians story throughout the other marvel movies you will not be dissatisfied with this entry. It's an absolute must see and the perfect ending to a brilliant story. It's been a long time since marvel has felt like it delivered. Trust the strong reviews because you must not skip this movie!

Fun, darkly wonderful, awesome. Enjotable. Complex. Emotional- may need tissue. Great development of Rocket. Good old sci-fi battles. Excellent Nemesis. Holds up well to the others. Enough loose ends to ......be continued. Enough fodder to form multiple spin-offs. Tons of Easter eggs. And as always great music.

The back story for Rocket is amazing and memorable. It's also the very dark part. Very. Dark.

And Groot!!!!! Did not see that coming.

The relationships between characters is genuine....and represents how close friends love each other at the same time they get on each others nerves.

2.5 hours flew by. Was engaged the entire time. Recommend it.

Guardians of the Galaxy Volume 3, and to some extent the whole trilogy, shows what a Marvel movie can be when it's allowed to be it's own thing and not beholden to furthering other projects. It has its flaws but the focus on character and satisfying resolutions make this one of the MCU's best efforts in years. In fact, one of its best ever.

The film begins with an attack on The Guardians by Adam Warlock, teased at the end of volume 2 and played brilliantly by Will Poulter as a gold dusted himbo, leading to Rocket being critically injured. This leaves the rest of the team in a race against time to track down a cure and brings them into conflict with the racoon's creator, The High Evolutionary.

They say that if you want the audience to hate a character just show the character kicking a puppy. By that metric The High Evolutionary will go down as one of the most despised villians in cinematic history. He's a full on animal abuser who's frustrations with life's imperfections give him no regard for the suffering of others and have him creating and genociding entire species on a whim. Played with an air of Shakesperian grandeur by Chukwudi Iwuji, The High Evolutionary makes a case for being the MCU's best villian to date.

Pretty much all the cast get time to shine and develope. Quill and the new (or is it old since she came form the past?) Gamora re develope their relationship but maybe not in the way you would expect, the change in Nebula over the course of three films is visable and believable, returning the favour from Volume 2 Mantis helps the others see Drax's worth and Kraglin gets his chance to live up to his old boss Yondu. The only one who doesn't see much development is Groot, who is curiously on the periphery of preceedings while his closest companion is in mortal danger. While Rocket is in many ways the main protagonist of the film he mostly appears in flashbacks as a very different character than the smart mouthed rodent we have come to know and his banter with the rest of the team is missed.

Making the stakes more personal rather than more epic for the conclusion of the trilogy is an unusual move in a genre that tends to favour spectacle but its a fitting send off for a series that has always placed the emphasise on its characters. That's not to say there isn't plenty of bang for your buck, with action scenes aplenty and the traditional drawn out MCU final act that makes the movie longer than it needs to be. It's also, like it's predecessors, actually funny and packs in some of the best gags Marvel has to offer, even if it could be accused of going lowest common denominator a couple of times too often. Its not all laughs though, throwaway jokes and humour filled chats are mixed with some truly dark events.

Is it too dark? No, but if you have young kids I'd check this out on your own before deciding if they can handle it. James Gunn is a filmmaker who has never been afraid of playing away from the light and on his final hurrah for the mouse house he doesn't hold back. There are multiple scenes of cute things in distress and some visual grotesquery that reminds you that the director of Slither is behind the camera. One shot in particular (you'll know it when you see it) stretches the level of gore you can get away with in a family film to the absolute limit.

Volume 3 isn't perfectly paced and it may give you tonal whiplash but character and heart make Guardians of the Galaxy Volume 3 a fitting end to the most unique of Marvel trilogies.

It's a masterpiece, one of best marvel films, and absolutely one of best movies this year, inspiring acting, scenes that makes you cry , i cried 3 times in this movie, good screenplay and graphics UI in action scene and absolutely a good ending to this series , good story mix of comedy, action and adventure that makes you feel happy for more than 2 hours, every hero has it's own story, the developing of characters in this movie is very good , great acting and great story fall of love and passion and drama , absolutely a good experience especially in cinema , I recommend this movie for all family.

It was the phase 1 esque movie rather than phase 2 these days. Characters were already developed in pervious movies, except the main villain but even he fael perfectly into place. Characters were picked in a great way which can emotionally attract audience. Unlike thor love and thunder, humour also falls into place. No weird comedy was a great relief. Almost all the scenes were engaging.

One of the thing I did not like was orgosphere and the execution of the concept.

One thing marvel again went back to phase 2 was it post credit scenes. They are mocking audience with their dumb post credits.

Overall a nice movie with lot of emotions which I would like to watch again. Fell more in love with Rocket.

After watching all new marvel movies, which ended up being so bad, I need to question my self, is it really a Marvel movie? Because the message of the movie, story of the movie, emotions and everything are out of (recent) Marvel league... I don't know why I'm so blown away with this movie, maybe because, hands down, we are not getting good movies recently... But, man, I was crying almost constantly. It was so powerful and honestly raw, and I loved it. And really nice way to summarizing whole story, opening doors for new developments. I hope they will stay on this track with new movies production, it would be sad to see if they miss this opportunity... And honestly, they gave a lot to the fans, so I think pressure and expectations are really high!

Marvels dissapointing movie (and series) streak ends with GOTG3 and they absolutely nailed it. The movie had everything good action cinema needs to have and still remains true to their concept.

It is goofy and funny as always, but instead of making jokes all 3 sentences they picked out good spots and wrote actual funny punchlines.


The movie will probably make you cry sooner or later. It is rare that a movie makes me emotional, but this one certainly did






All in all it is fair to say that James Gunn has done it once again and really nailed the last adventure of our favourite Marvel characters. Definitely worth a second watch!

I understand why this movie has seen success as another "Marvel Standard" installment in the franchise. It has great action scenes, stunning visuals and Marvel's quintessential quick-wit writing we all have come to love.

However, this was still the first time I have ever walked out on a Marvel film.

I walked out because I am particularly sensitive to animal cruelty and, unfortunately, the plot of the film revolves around intergalactic animal torture.

The film does not pull any punches when it comes to tugging at one's heartstrings in this respect, as other Guardians Volumes have. What I expected to be a fun romp with a familiar crew, left me feeling only disturbed and sad.

I would argue that this film took the exploration of animal cruelty too far, and I would not take my children to see the film.

Easily the best MCU movie post Endgame. I was kind of nervous going into it as I really didnt like The Holiday Special, but I think he hit the right tone with it still being funny yet serious. Even the ending was perfectly bittersweet. Incredibly touching and poignant. I definitely cried more than once. The film deals with themes of eugenics and animal cruelty and while it definitely be hard to watch at times, I think James Gunn did a good job with it.

Things I specifically liked - Rocket. Easily the heart and soul of the film. He doesnt have much action in this film. Most of his scenes are flashbacks. But completely integral to the plot and adding dimension to his character. He'll break your heart for sure. The High Evolutionary was honestly one of the best villains we have got so far. Has to be one of the most evil, most heartless villains. Nebula was great as well. I loved how far her character has come and how much she has grown. Despite being mostly robotic at this point, she is the most human here. I also really did like Will Poulter as Adam Warlock, though he doesnt get much to do in this film. I dont think he was necessary to this specific film so it feels kind of wasted. Though Im excited to see what else they can do with him, if they decide to bring him back.

Speaking of things being a waste, the f bomb. I had heard before going into the movie that this would be the MCU's first f bomb, and so when I heard it in the movie, I was like "This is the moment you used it on?". Could of have been cooler and more significant. But I mean, thats such a small thing to gripe about. Even though I did love getting more of Rocket's backstory, I did think a lot of the interactions with Lila, Teefs and Floor were cheesy and a little too on the nose. I also dont think Gamora was really needed in this movie either. I mean...she was kind of integral in a way to help Peter move on and accept his loss - but as a character herself she didnt really add anything and I was a bit disappointed with that. I didnt find the Nathan Fillion cameo all that funny either.

But other than that, I really loved the film and again...I think probably the best MCU film post Endgame. (Although I did also really love Shang Chi so I would maybe have to re-watch that).

The film ended up being excellent, breathtaking, mesmerizing and funny every way. Character development, story, visual effects, music and humor was so balanced and everything that make it one of the best marvel studios' movies ever. The anti-heroes also appeared normally, especially Adam Warlock, who is probably more of a hidden villain, although this way of James Gunn is understandable. All the characters seem like protagonists. None of them are over/under rated and all are at the right place at the right time. The point is that the film, which is associated with one particular group, should be unified, and here it was. Finally, go and watch it, now!

Music: 10/10 Storytelling: 10/10 Characters: 10/10 Special Effects: 9/10 Action: 10/10

Overall 9/10

Music has always been a large part of the Guardians of the Galaxy since day one. So this outing is no different and employs each song with great effect. Evoking emotions both from my own personal experiences with the track and how it relates to what is happening onscreen.

The elements of story, humour and dark moments are so well balanced that while you are preoccupied with the retelling of past events in the history of one of the main characters. You will feel the emotion from the dark moments and then get blindsided by the wacky humour the next. Very well done!

The special effects are so well done that it makes everything onscreen feel alot more authentic. Of course they are not completely perfect. But close enough and it makes the action so much more fun!

This is the best MCU movie. It has the perfect amount of action, emotion, comedy, the pacing is great and the vibe is amazing. It truly was the best way to close the trilogy.

It's crazy how when infinity war / end game dropped most of us thought peak marvel was over, even pushing it to nhw, but nope, I guess it's still possible to create masterpieces - and this is one of them.

After the new antman this was really refreshing, the last couple mcu movies have been painfully average.

It's really sad that gotg is over, but the ending does give hope that we can continue to see some of the characters in the future.

And lastly, that hallway fight scene, is probably the best fight scene since end game.

I put this movie on hold, and although I really like Guardians of the Galaxy, I just wanted to let the hype surrounding it settle down before watching it. This outing for the franchise is perfect and serves as a spectacular reminder of how good Marvel movies can be when there is enough clarity, subtlety, and heart put into the story. It focuses more on the characters' journey, allowing the audience to connect with them on a deeper level and find elements that make them special. This movie evokes strong emotions and can be challenging to watch at times, mainly due to the incredible Rocket story that finally reveals the depths of what this beloved character has endured. This Marvel film stands out as one of the most emotionally engaging ones that I can remember, and I will always be grateful for that. The performances from the entire cast are exactly what you would expect-dynamic and enjoyable. It has been quite some time since we had such a formidable main villain that you can't help but root for their demise. The High Evolutionary reigns supreme with his narcissistic and evil demeanor. Both James Gunn's writing and Chukwudi Iwuji's acting seamlessly come together in an impressive fashion.

Another fantastic element of this film is that you can see the group of heroes is somewhat weary and worn out, as if they have reached the end of their rope. However, it is precisely their teamwork and camaraderie that make them resilient and unparalleled when it comes to protecting the universe. Their collective strength shines through, emphasizing the power of their bond. The fact that these characters have gone through significant challenges and personal growth throughout their journeys makes them even more endearing and relatable to audiences. While there may be a few minor negatives that one can point out, ultimately, they don't significantly detract from the overall experience. Guardians of the Galaxy Volume 3 stands out as one of the best Marvel comic book movies of all time. It carries a remarkable sense of gravitas and showcases incredible filmmaking throughout. There are different perspectives regarding the future of the Guardians of the Galaxy franchise. Some might hope that this film marks the end of their journey, believing it's a fitting conclusion. Others may see it as an intriguing starting point for a new team that could embark on further dangerous adventures. However, one thing is certain: regardless of the franchise's direction, it's important to express gratitude to James Gunn and the entire crew for their efforts in creating this movie. Their contributions have played a significant role in shaping the Guardians of the Galaxy and providing audiences with memorable cinematic experiences.

My Review- Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 (2023) My Rating 7.5 /10

I'll admit Cartoon Super heroes are really not my specialty and a little out of my comfort zone however I was entertained and enjoyed the escapades of Star Lord Peter Quill played by Chris Pratt as well as my favourite character Rocky Racoon sorry Rocket Racoon voice supplied by Bradley Cooper ,Drax the warrior played by Dave Bautista ,Nebula the adopted sister of Gamora played by Karen Gillan and my 2nd favourite character Groot a member of the Guardians who is a tree-like humanoid and the accomplice of Rocket .

I mean it as a compliment that Groot Played by Vin Diesel gave a very wooden performance in a role that gave him plenty of opportunity to branch out .

I enjoyed the light comedy touches in Galaxy 3 and the chemistry that the comrades in arms had together it gives the story a human touch .

Although saying that the humans or humanoids are few and far between ,especially on Counter Earth a planet created by the villain of the movie titled The High Evolutionary a scientist played by Chukwudi Iwuji . This Classic mad scientist has populated Counter Earth with his created anthropomorphic animal creatures that mimic the everyday lives of our planet Earth which has destroyed itself with corruption and War.

The movie opens on a planet or place called Nowhere which reminded me very much of the seedy Cantina bar scene in Star Wars where we're introduced to characters just as strange and just as seedy.

The action begins with an attack from a warrior Adam Warlock who critically wounds Rocket which sets the action when the Guardians are unable to tend to Rockets wounds prompting Peter Quill to sets off find the combination of the kill switch embedded in the beloved raccoons head to save his life .

It's a fun and exciting romp of a movie reminding me of the Saturday matinee movies I grew up watching .

Whether it's Our Gang, The Three Musketeers, Harry Potter and his Gryffindors or The Magnificent Seven buddy movies have audience appeal so I suspect this is the case with The Guardians.

Where todays Saturday matinee movies differ of course is due to the technology as they are certainly more spectacular of course .

They are far more innovative as they would be with a Production budget that any treasurer would be envious of .

"Guardians of the Galaxy 3" cost $250 million to produce and roughly $100 million to promote fortunately for Disney its a huge box office hit already with a $528.8 million in global sales in its second weekend in theatres.

There's fortunes to be made for all in The Guardians of the Galaxy movie franchise including it's star Chris Pratt . His father in law Arnold Schwarzenegger put his full support behind his son in law and was very proud of the result.

Chris Pratt's estimated net worth to date is $80 million not bad since his first Galaxy movie was filmed only nine years ago.

I imagine Disney were pleased to welcome Director and screenwriter James Gunn back to the fold after his dismissal in 2018 his contribution is obviously crucial to the box office success of Guardians of the Galaxy.

As a fan of both Is marvel and the guardians of the galaxy Wow all I can say is well this was the entire triology And it's no secret why it's doing very well at the Box office. And I personally thought That this Film Very emotional and serious but also funny and It's what you'd expect from a guardian of the Galaxy Film And the interaction Of Adam warlock in this film was very good but and this film perfectly sets up another sequel with rocket As The leader and Adam warlock joins the team which I can't wait for and I also can't wait for whatevor movie or TV show. They do. With starlord recommend it.

James Gunn is, as always, an excellent movie. It made me laugh and cry so much. It was perfect, down to the minor details.

It's a great move for them to continue the story through rocket. His story is so sad I cried so much that I can't tell you. The songs and visual effect were so great. James Gunn needs to make more movies. They finished Guardians of the galaxy in the best way, The perfect ending. All the characters were very well written, very nice. It was the best marvel movie to come out after Endgame. I loved this movie. It was so beautiful and now I won't be able to write anymore and I'm doing it blank.

In short terms, if you've seen 1-2 and enjoyed most of the MCU movies than you're in for a treat!
